channel.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News: TOI brings the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: US deploys more ballistic missile defences in Middle East to protect Israel
item.description: The United States has enhanced its military presence in the Middle East by deploying additional ballistic missile defence destroyers, fighter squadrons, tanker aircraft, and B-52 bombers. This move aims to protect US interests, defend Israel, and promote de-escalation through diplomacy. The US warned Iran against targeting American personnel.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Faith bird that feels light when dawn is still dark': US secretary of state Antony Blinken quotes Rabindranath Tagore at Diwali celebrations
item.description: US secretary of state Antony Blinken highlighted Rabindranath Tagore's words at the state department’s Diwali reception. President Biden and vice president Harris participated, recognizing Diwali's significance. Biden hosted a record Diwali event at the White House, inviting around 600 Indian-Americans.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Fake video depicting voter fraud in Georgia part of Russian misinformation campaign: US
item.description: US intelligence officials reveal a fabricated video by Russian operatives claiming voter fraud in Georgia, cautioning continued foreign election interference. The FBI and other agencies proactively address disinformation, identifying this as part of Russia's effort to undermine election trust and divide Americans.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Gay Trump supporter explains why Trump has 'normal gays'
item.description: Ohio Senator JD Vance, on Joe Rogan's podcast, discussed LGBTQ+ rights, focusing on medical interventions for gender transitions. Vance and Rogan questioned the support for early gender transition policies. Trump’s record on LGBTQ+ issues was highlighted, including the appointment of the first openly gay cabinet member and efforts to end HIV/AIDS transmission.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Kamala Harris vows to end 'unnecessary' degree requirements for federal jobs on day one
item.description: Kamala Harris pledged to eliminate unnecessary degree requirements for federal jobs via executive order on her first day as president. Addressing a crowd in Janesville, she emphasized this move's potential to broaden access to federal employment and challenged the private sector to follow suit. Harris’s proposal builds on the Biden administration’s push for skills-based hiring.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Elon Musk reacts to reports that he could be deported for immigration violation
item.description: Elon Musk is from South Africa and he dismissed allegations that he violated US immigration law. Even President Joe Biden spoke about the issue as he said, "That wealthiest man in the world turned out to be an illegal worker here when he was here." “He was supposed to be in school when he came on a student visa. He wasn’t in school. He was violating the law. He’s talking about all these ‘illegals’ coming our way,” Biden said.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Watch: Hugh Hewitt storms out of Washington Post live saying 'I'm done', resigns
item.description: ​When Hewitt's turn came to speak he said the news needed to be reported. “Bucks County was reversed by the court and instructed to open up extra days because they violated the law and told people to go home,” he said. ​​Capehart told Hewitt, “I don’t appreciate being lectured about reporting when, Hugh, many times you come here saying lots of things that aren’t based in fact.” “I won’t come back, Jonathan, I’m done,” he said. “You guys are working, that’s fine, I’m done.”
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Lying Liz'? Did Donald Trump call for Liz Cheney's execution? Here's the truth
item.description: "This is how dictators destroy free nations. They threaten those who speak against them with death. We cannot entrust our country and our freedom to a petty, vindictive, cruel, unstable man who wants to be a tyrant," Liz Cheney said. The Republicans condemned the use of "death" in her reaction and claimed Trump never wished for Liz Cheney's death -- what Trump meant is 'war hawk' Liz Cheney should be sent to war, otherwise the warmonger Democrats will keep on sending troops sitting in Washington.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Three dead, three injured in Halloween house party shooting in Colorado
item.description: A tragic Halloween house party in Northglenn, Denver, ended in gunfire, killing three and injuring three others just past midnight. Police found one deceased victim at the scene, while two more died after being hospitalized. No suspects have been apprehended, though officials state there are no public threats at this time.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Mark Cuban clarifies 'intelligent women' comment after Elon Musk's mother roasts Harris
item.description: Mark Cuban clarified that he knows many strong, intelligent women voting for Trump "including in my extended family". "I'm certainly not saying female voters are not smart, strong and intelligent. I know he has worked with strong intelligent women, like Elaine Chao, Kelly Anne, Ivanka and many others. I stand by my opinion that he does not like being challenged publicly," he wrote.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Watch: Moment police tackle teen gunman who opened fire at Orlando Halloween event
item.description: A 17-year-old suspect, Jaylen Dwayne Edgar, was captured on surveillance footage firing shots at a Halloween event in downtown Orlando, resulting in two deaths and six injuries. A quick-acting police officer apprehended him. The incident occurred around 1 am, drawing a heavy law enforcement response among the large crowd of tens of thousands of celebrants.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Epstein showed photos of Trump with topless women, he could ruin Donald, claims author
item.description: According to Michael Wolff, Epstein used to believe he could ruin Trump as he had such evidence with him. Trump had the habit of pitting his own people against each other while his competition was with Epstein over women. Trump and Epstein apparently shared a girlfriend and Epstein hinted that outscoring each other on women was a "high sport" for Trump. But Epstein was also afraid of Trump knowing he would do anything to protect himself.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Meghan and Harry feel life US hasn't been what they expected: Ex-staff
item.description: Both Meghan and Harry became less popular after they exited the royal family and moved to California -- despite their several tell-all accounts against the family. Harry and Meghan have separated their professional ways as their Sussexes brand so far failed to make them popular in the United States. Meghan's Hollywood dream also could not take off.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US Election Top 10: Decoding Donald Trump’s massive Hindu outreach on Diwali
item.description: Donald Trump’s Diwali outreach has stirred interest among Hindu Americans, a group traditionally loyal to Democrats. Trump’s remarks focused on condemning violence against Hindus in Bangladesh, opposing California’s caste bill, and promising stronger ties with Indian PM Narendra Modi. This approach contrasts with Kamala Harris, who has faced criticism for her perceived lack of connection to her Indian heritage. With influential figures like Vivek Ramaswamy supporting Trump, there’s a growing interest among Hindu Americans in the GOP. This election cycle reflects the increasing significance of Indian American voters as both parties vie for their support.
item.dc:creator: Nirmalya Dutta

item.title: Nate Silver says pollsters lying about Trump-Harris close race: 'F**king finger on the scale'
item.description: In his final prediction, Silver said his forecasts are extremely stable. "Kamala Harris' winning odds are 46.2 per cent and Donald Trump's are 53.4 per cent. That's very close to a coin flip, in other words," Silver's prediction early Thursday said. Late on Thursday, he updated that it will be "decidedly rougher for Harris".
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Jennifer Lopez trolled for almost crying over 'Puerto Rico joke': 'You dated P Diddy'
item.description: Social media users asked her what she did for Puerto Rico and that her ex-boyfriend was Diddy, arrested for sex trafficking. "If you were a regular at P.Diddy's parties, there's a 100% chance you'll endorse Kamala Harris," Catturd posted. As LeBron James also endorsed Kamala Harris, the detractors doubled down on Kamala Harris and asked how all Diddy party attendees ended up in Kamala Harris campaign.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Spain’s Valencia region reels from deadliest floods in decades: Why did over 205 lives end in tragedy?
item.description: Eastern Spain faces its deadliest flooding in Valencia, resulting in over 205 deaths. Torrential rains caused flash floods, worsened by climate change and poor urban planning. Late warnings and lack of risk awareness further contribute to the disaster, highlighting the need for improved emergency education.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: North Korea claims new missile as 'world’s strongest,' but experts raise concerns over size
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Severe flooding in Pakistan's Sindh province has left thousands of people suffering: Rights group
item.description: Amnesty International criticizes the Pakistan government's failure to provide essential services for thousands of Sindhi flood victims, who face heightened health risks and lost livelihoods amid stagnant floodwaters. Many affected communities are still suffering from inaction and a lack of support months after the devastating August 2024 floods.

item.title: The Economist endorses VP: List of newspapers supporting Kamala Harris
item.description: The Economist in its endorsement said if Donald Trump wins the election, Americans would be gambling with the economy, the rule of law and international peace. Kama Harris' shortcomings, on the other hand, are ordinary and none of them are disqualifying, they said. "If The Economist had a vote, we would cat it for her," The Economist said.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
